newsitem.title: USA: Conseco buys insurance firms for more than $1.7 billion.
newsitem.headline: Conseco buys insurance firms for more than $1.7 billion.

text.p: Life insurance and financial services giant Conseco Inc. said Monday it would acquire two insurance companies and increase its stakes in two others in deals having a total price tag of more than $1.7 billion.
The Carmel, Ind.-based company said it would acquire American Travellers Corp., which provides long-term care insurance, for $793 million in Conseco stock.
It also said it agreed to buy Capitol American Financial Corp., a provider of cancer insurance and other supplemental health insurance, for $650 milion in cash and Conseco stock.

Conseco said it intends to acquire the stock of American Life Holdings that it does not alredy own for $165 million in cash. It said it would distribute the stock of American Life that had been held by Conseco Capital Partners II LP to all partners. American Life is a provider of retirement savings annuities.

Conseco also said it will acquire the remaining shares of Bankers Life Holding Corp. that it does not already own for $117 million and intends to merge with the provider of supplemental health insurance products for senior citizens.
Conseco's stock gained $1 to $43 in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange, while American Travellers shot up $2.875 to $31.25 on the Nasdaq market.
American Life was unchanged at $24 on Nasdaq. Bankers Life Holding gained $1.875 to $23.625 and Capitol American Financial was untraded after a pre-weekend close of $25, both on the NYSE.

After the transactions are completed, Conseco said it will have $30 billion of assets under management, $26 billion of assets on its balance sheet, $6.8 billion of annual premiums and revenues, $4.2 billion of equity market capitalisation and more than $650 million of projected annual earnings.
"The life insurance industry is undergoing rapid consolidation," said Conseco Chairman Stephen Hilbert. "Conseco is positioned as a proven consolidator."

"After the transactions, Conseco expects to have $5.4 billion of total capital, comprised of $3.5 billion of equity, including the planned issuance of about $300 million of a new tax-deductible preferred stock and assuming the conversion of all convertible instruments, and $1.9 billion of debt," he said.
Hilbert said that the acquisitions will boost the company's 1997 operating earnings.

"Assuming completion of these transactions before the end of 1996, as expected, we believe Conseco's operating earnings will be able to reach our previously announced goal of $5.00 per fully diluted share in 1997, compared to current analyst expectations of $4.25 to $4.65," Hilbert said.
He said the company is focusing on acquisitions that complement its long-term business strategy and maintain both its earnings momentum and its conservative capital structure.
